Does it actually double the amount of RAM *used* or the amount of RAM *addressable*?
every memory address becomes double the size it was, everything doubles in ram
If an address that was 0xabcdef11 is now 0x00000000abcdef11, how has that doubled memory use?
Having just been schooled in DNS I'm trying to be cautious here. ;)
Every address is twice the size it was at 32 bits, so allocating one address that used to be 32 bits of memory is now 64 bits of memory
vlt: Oh, because what used to be enough space for two addresses in 32-bit is now only enough for one in 64-bit.
exactly
